name.namePart: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MELVILLE ProjectID: HI453MEL_M From: 2008-07-01 To: 2008-09-01

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 322 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI453MEL_M from HMAS MELVILLE.
The CTD was manufactured by Applied Microsystems Limited and is the "Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the MVP200_CTD. This CTD is fitted with a 4 electrode platinized conductivity cell, thermistor temperature sensor and a semiconductor strain gauge pressure sensor.
The CTD sensors are calibrated at the manufacturer Applied Microsystems Limited on a 12-18 month schedule. The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated against 'Hart' temperature standards. The pressure sensor is calibrated using 'Budenburg Deadweight' standards. The conductivity sensor is calibrated using 'Hart' temperature standards and seawater samples of known conductivity.
The CTD sensors are mounted to a fish-shape probe. The probe is controlled by an electric winch (MVP200 type). For downcasts the fish is allowed to free-fall (winch is in 'free-wheel' mode) under its own weight at about 2-3 ms-1 and then is winched back. Data is recorded in downcast and usually in upcast direction at a sampling rate of 25 Hz. The downcast data is of higher quality because sensors encounter undisturbed seawater that flows through the nose of the fish. On the upcast the fish is flipped around (tail first) and the sensors in the nose encounter disturbed flow from the fish tail.
This type of CTD is prone to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' caused by a mismatch between the response times of the temperature and conductivity sensor. Data undergoes a salinity de-spiking routine to correct for this. See the history metadata for further details on the salinity de-spiking process.
Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Byron Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBYB) - Deployment No. 18 14-MAY-1992 to 18-JUN-1993

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.698611, longitude 153.746111 and water depth 73 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.822500, longitude 153.665556 and water depth 62 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

name.namePart: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MELVILLE ProjectID: SRATA-0135MEL_M From: 2008-01-17 To: 2008-01-20

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 86 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise SRATA-0135MEL_M from HMAS MELVILLE.
The CTD was manufactured by Applied Microsystems Limited and is the "Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the MVP200_CTD. This CTD is fitted with a 4 electrode platinized conductivity cell, thermistor temperature sensor and a semiconductor strain gauge pressure sensor.
The CTD sensors are calibrated at the manufacturer Applied Microsystems Limited on a 12-18 month schedule. The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated against 'Hart' temperature standards. The pressure sensor is calibrated using 'Budenburg Deadweight' standards. The conductivity sensor is calibrated using 'Hart' temperature standards and seawater samples of known conductivity.
The CTD sensors are mounted to a fish-shape probe. The probe is controlled by an electric winch (MVP200 type). For downcasts the fish is allowed to free-fall (winch is in 'free-wheel' mode) under its own weight at about 2-3 ms-1 and then is winched back. Data is recorded in downcast and usually in upcast direction at a sampling rate of 25 Hz. The downcast data is of higher quality because sensors encounter undisturbed seawater that flows through the nose of the fish. On the upcast the fish is flipped around (tail first) and the sensors in the nose encounter disturbed flow from the fish tail.
This type of CTD is prone to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' caused by a mismatch between the response times of the temperature and conductivity sensor. Data undergoes a salinity de-spiking routine to correct for this. See the history metadata for further details on the salinity de-spiking process.
Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS LEEUWIN ProjectID: HI488LEE_H From: 2011-02-12 To: 2011-02-21

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 2 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI488LEE_H from HMAS LEEUWIN.
The CTD was manufactured by Falmouth Scientific and is the "2-inch Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the HS_CTD. This CTD is fitted within an inductive type conductivity cell, a platinum thermometer and silicon pressure sensor.
The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated on the ITS-90 temperature scale against a master CTD using a controlled temperature bath. The pressure sensor is calibrated using a Druck Pressure Calibrator. The conductivity sensor is calibrated in a temperature controlled bath against seawater samples of known conductivity.
The HS_CTD is lowered and raised by a hand winch sampling at a rate of 1.83 Hz. Data files were recorded in the downcast and upcast direction but most data is from downcasts due to higher quality. Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals and converted to netCDF format files. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: RAN Sea Surface Temperature Data - HMAS BRISBANE CruiseID: SST_09BS_1977_16 From: 1977-04-28 To: 1977-09-22

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 134 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Brisbane. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.

name.namePart: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS LEEUWIN ProjectID: HI444LEE_H From: 2007-07-30 To: 2007-08-10

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 7 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI444LEE_H from HMAS LEEUWIN.
The CTD was manufactured by Falmouth Scientific and is the "2-inch Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the HS_CTD. This CTD is fitted within an inductive type conductivity cell, a platinum thermometer and silicon pressure sensor.
The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated on the ITS-90 temperature scale against a master CTD using a controlled temperature bath. The pressure sensor is calibrated using a Druck Pressure Calibrator. The conductivity sensor is calibrated in a temperature controlled bath against seawater samples of known conductivity.
The HS_CTD is lowered and raised by a hand winch sampling at a rate of 1.83 Hz. Data files were recorded in the downcast and upcast direction but most data is from downcasts due to higher quality. Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals and converted to netCDF format files. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: RAN Sea Surface Temperature Data - HMAS VENDETTA CruiseID: SST_09VE_1974_06 From: 1974-09-16 To: 1974-09-20

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 24 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Vendetta. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Port Kembla Offshore Wave Data (WAVEPOK) - Deployment No. 2 25-OCT-1976 to 16-NOV-1983

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description: This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Port Kembla at latitude -34.451111, longitude 150.996389 and water depth 50 metres. The data is gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

name.namePart: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MELVILLE ProjectID: HI470MEL_H From: 2009-11-16 To: 2009-11-16

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 1 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI470MEL_H from HMAS MELVILLE.
The CTD was manufactured by Falmouth Scientific and is the "2-inch Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the HS_CTD. This CTD is fitted within an inductive type conductivity cell, a platinum thermometer and silicon pressure sensor.
The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated on the ITS-90 temperature scale against a master CTD using a controlled temperature bath. The pressure sensor is calibrated using a Druck Pressure Calibrator. The conductivity sensor is calibrated in a temperature controlled bath against seawater samples of known conductivity.
The HS_CTD is lowered and raised by a hand winch sampling at a rate of 1.83 Hz. Data files were recorded in the downcast and upcast direction but most data is from downcasts due to higher quality. Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals and converted to netCDF format files. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.
Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.
Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

name.namePart: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Byron Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBYB) - Deployment No. 2 03-AUG-1978 to 13-JUN-1979

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.640000, longitude 153.721667 and water depth 70 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

name.namePart: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Byron Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBYB) - Deployment No. 30 20-AUG-2009 to 31-DEC-2010

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.853889, longitude 153.701944 and water depth 62 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description: This dataset contains sea surface temperature measurements for Linley Point Channel, collected by the NSW DECCW Beachwatch section for the Beachwatch monitoring program. Temperature data is unverified and collected on an ad-hoc basis in conjunction with the Beachwatch bacteria sampling and monitoring program. Selected beaches are normally sampled every 6 days. See http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/beachapp/default.aspx for further details about the Beachwatch program.
Collected in conjunction with bacterial data in and around various Sydney beach sites as part of a long term monitoring program.
NSW Department of Environment and Climate Change (DECCW) Beachwatch section

name.namePart: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Port Kembla Offshore Wave Data (WAVEPOK) - Deployment No. 6 19-JAN-1989 to 25-JAN-1990

collection.subject: oceans
oceans
collection.description: This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Port Kembla at latitude -34.475000, longitude 151.018333 and water depth 73 metres. The data is gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.
Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory
